body.p: The release engineering team (re@FreeBSD.org) for FreeBSD 4.5 consists of Murray Stokely, Steve Price, Robert Watson, and John Baldwin.
The x86 build team consists of Murray Stokely and John Baldwin.
The Alpha build team consists of David O'Brien, Wilko Bulte, John Baldwin, and Murray Stokely.
The third-party packages are handled by Steve Price and the Ports managers (portmgr@FreeBSD.org).
General discussions about the release engineering process or quality assurance issues should be sent to the public freebsd-qa mailing list. MFC requests should be sent to re@FreeBSD.org.
For an overview of the entire release engineering process, please see this document.

tr.td: Release Engineers send announcement email to developers@FreeBSD.org with a rough schedule for the FreeBSD 4.5 release.

After this date, all commits to the RELENG_4 branch must be approved by re@FreeBSD.org. Certain highly active documentation committers are exempt from this rule for routine man page / release note updates. Heads-up emails should be sent to the developers@, stable@, and qa@ lists.
The second disc contains commercial software demos, these demos should be updated to contain the latest versions.
Someone from portmgr should email freebsd-ports@ and CC: developers@ to set a date for the tagging of the ports tree. Will set this date at January 22nd.
A message should be sent to freebsd-hubs@FreeBSD.org before the release is uploaded. The site administrators have frequently requested advance notice for new ISOs.

The first release candidate for the x86 and Alpha architecture is released. ISO images should be uploaded to ftp-master.FreeBSD.org and releng4.FreeBSD.org. A network install directory should be uploaded to ftp-master.FreeBSD.org. The packages and XF86336 directories may be symlinked to save space, as long as you're sure to use relative symlinks.
A message should be sent to qa@FreeBSD.org and stable@FreeBSD.org after the release is uploaded.
Note: the release date of this candidate depends on the user experience with RC1.
4.5 RC3 for the x86 and Alpha architectures will be made available from ftp.FreeBSD.org and the mirrors.

CVSROOT/avail locks out everyone but the person who does the tagging. It will take approximately 2 hours to tag the entire ports tree with the RELEASE_4_5_0 tag. After this time, the ports/ tree will be re-opened for commits, but commits made after tagging will not go in 4.5-RELEASE.
The ports cluster and bento build final packages.
The packages must be split so that packages with similar dependencies appear on each of the four discs, with the most popular packages appearing on the first disc.

A note should be sent to the freebsd-stable to let over-anxious users know that the tags have been created but the release still isn't ready. Tags may be slid before the announcement goes out. Point users to freebsd-qa@ for details.
The files listed here are updated to reflect the fact that this is FreeBSD 4.5.
Make sure the 4.5 manual pages are being displayed by default for the man->web gateway.
The new RELNOTESng errata file should be setup, and the old errata file archived.
Final builds for x86 and Alpha in a pristine environment.
Heads up email to hubs@FreeBSD.org to give admins time to prepare for the load spike to come.
release and packages uploaded to ftp-master.FreeBSD.org
Announcement sent out after a majority of the mirrors have received the bits.

body.p: It's been pointed out that this table is rather boring. Bruce Mah gave a slightly more interesting rendition of the 12 days of Code-Freeze.
